Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: EMSW21-RTG: JOINT COLUMBIA-CUNY-NYU RESEARCH TRAINING GROUP IN NUMBER THEORY
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the RTG proposal is to make the New York metropolitan area a premier world center and model for the study of number theory. The project is a joint training effort involving three universities (Columbia-CUNY-NYU) with eight principal investigators and twenty-five other faculty all working in number theory and related areas. The Columbia-CUNY-NYU team will develop nine new graduate courses for the design of a city-wide graduate number theory curriculum with more active training methods such as workshops, presentations by students, and opportunities to develop technical lecturing, computer programming, and writing skills. The new graduate courses will go beyond the existing first year courses (commutative
algebra/algebraic geometry, algebraic number theory) and will cover
a broad range of core topics (required for cutting edge research) such as: arithmetic geometry, automorphic representations, spectral theory, and combinatorial number theory. In addition, six new or restructured undergraduate courses will be developed and an annual undergraduate summer research program and graduate summer school (meeting once every 3 years) will be created. The recently created Columbia-CUNY-NYU Number Theory Seminar will be redesigned, making it more accessible to students and more vibrant for seminal research. A central goal is to provide an environment where postdocs, graduate students, undergraduates, and faculty from the entire New York metropolitan area study and work together in a collaborative atmosphere that fosters research and development.

Number theory is one of the oldest and most fundamental branches of mathematics. Basic research in number theory has led to important applications in computer science and cryptography. Recent spectacular breakthroughs in the subject such as the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem by Taylor-Wiles require an understanding of an enormous amount of mathematics, much of it outside number theory. It is not sufficient any more for beginning students to study a small segment of number theory. The eight PI's of this proposal (Goldfeld, Kolyvagin, Kramer, Szpiro, Tschinkel, Urban, Venkatesh, Zhang) have extensive overlapping interests but their combined expertise covers all of modern number theory. The scientific research interests of the
team include algebraic/arithmetic geometry, hyperbolic geometry,
automorphic forms and representations, Langlands program, analytic number theory, spectral theory, ergodic theory, Lie algebras, algebraic number theory, elliptic curves, dynamical systems, and cryptography. This project will be decisive in raising the level of number theory across participating campuses: cross-pollinating successful ideas already in existence, and creating approaches through collective interaction. It is hoped that this RTG will become a national model for other programs of this kind.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project achieved its major goals:  to develop cutting-edge training and research in number theory in the New York City area and to foster the collaboration of experts at the Graduate and University Center of the City University of NY with those at Columbia University and New York University.  

The participants have published advances in various subspecialties of number theory, including arithmetic geometry, algebraic dynamics, modular forms and abelian varieties.  These works appeared in highly regarded, peer-refereed journals and were presented at seminars in the US and internationally.

Kenneth Kramer
1. Large Galois image and non-existence of certain abelian surfaces over Q , (with A. Brumer), in preparation, 20 pp.
2. Certain abelian varieties bad at only one prime , (with A. Brumer), Math ArXiv 1510.06249, 38 pp.
3. Explicit determination of root numbers of abelian varieties , (with A. Brumer, M. Sabitova), Accepted by Trans. AMS, Nov 2016, 15 pages.
4. Categoricity properties for computable algebraic elds , (with D. Hirschfeldt, R. Miller, A. Shlapentokh), Trans. AMS, 367  (2015), 3955-3980.
5. On higher congruences between automorphic forms , (with T. Berger, K. Klosin), Math. Res. Lett. 21(2014), 71-82.
6. Paramodular abelian varieties of odd conductor , (with A. Brumer), Trans. AMS, 366  (2014), 2463-2516.
7. Arithmetic of division elds , (with A. Brumer), Proc. AMS. 140  (2012), 2981-2995.
8. Noncomputable functions in the Blum-Shub-Smale model , (with W. Calvert, R. Miller), Log. Meth. Comp. Sci. 2011, Special issue: 7th International Conference on Computability and Complexity in Analysis (CCA 2010), 2:15, 20 pp.
9. The Cardinality of an Oracle in Blum-Shub-Smale Computation , (with W. Calvert, R. Miller), in Proceedings: Seventh International Conference on Computability and Complexity in Analysis, (eds. X. Zheng, N. Zhong), Electronic Proceedings in Theoretical Computer Science, 24  (2010), 56{66.

"Primes, permutations and primitive roots," New York Journal of Math 16(2010) 387-398.

3. (with C. Petsche and T. Tucker). “A dynamical pairing between two rational maps,” to appear Transactions of the AMS, (2010). arXiv:0911.1875  

4. (with A. Bhatnagar). “Very ample polarized self maps extend to projective space.” Journal of Algebra, Vol. 351, Issue 1,(2012), 251-253.

5. ( with M. Tepper and P. Williams). “Resultant and conductor of geometrically semi-stable self maps of the projective line over a function field.” (2010). arXiv:1010/5030.

6. (with B. Hutz. “Almost Newton, sometimes Latt`es” (2011). arXiv:1105.1695

7. (with M. Majidi-Zolbanin and N. Miasnikov.) “Lifting finite self maps of equicharacteristic complete local rings” (2011). arXiv:1105.1849

8. (with M. Majidi-Zolbanin and N. Miasnikov). “Dynamics and entropy in local algebra” (2011). arXiv:1109.6438 [51] with M. Majidi-Zolbanin and N. Miasnikov. “Kunz’ Regularity Criterion via algebraic entropy” (2011). arXiv:1110.3427

Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows were trained in the latest research methods in number theory.  In addition to the standard curriculum, new courses at an advanced level were offered.  Support provided by the project enabled the students to complete their work in a timely fashion.  The students and post-docs have gone on to influence a new generation of students of mathematics and mathematicians, as college professors and in industry.  

Ten students obtained the PhD in Mathematics with partial or total support from the RTG.

Undergraduates have been stimulated to pursue advanced study in mathematics and related areas (e.g. computer science and cryptography) through RTG outreach and course development.  Each year, a leading expert in number theory gave a special lecture aimed at undergraduates and interacted with undergraduates from many of the CUNY campuses.  The advanced undergraduate/master's level course in number theory at Queens College of CUNY was revised to provide more emphasis on recent developments and applications.  Several undergraduates from CUNY colleges are now enrolled in the Ph.D. program in mathematics at the Graduate Center.
